columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the net present value of a particular project using the concepts we learned in the chapter.

The net present value refers to the difference between the inflow and outflow of cash in a given project. A positive net present value means that the cash inflow is greater than the expenses which means that the project is profitable.

The problem states that their sausage system undergoes straight-line depreciation until it zeros out at the end of five years. This means that we can solve the depreciation by simply dividing the initial cost of the machine by the number of years:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\dfrac{\$460,000}{5}\\[15 pt]
&=\$92,000
\end{aligned}$$

The machine loses $\$92,000$ in value every year.

Since we already have the depreciation, we can then solve for the tax shield. The depreciation tax shield is the tax reduction which is computed by subtracting the depreciation value from the taxable income. To do this, we can simply multiply the depreciation by the tax rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax shield}&=\$92,000 \times 0.21\\[15 pt]
&=\$19,320
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation tax shield is $\$19,320$.

To solve for the tax, we can simply multiply the pre-tax savings by the tax rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax}&=\$155,000 \times 0.21\\[15 pt]
&=\$32,550
\end{aligned}$$

The tax for this project is $\$32,550$

Now that we have the necessary values, we can now solve for the operating cash flow which will be important in solving for the net present value. The operating cash flow is the amount of cash generated by this project. To solve for this, simply add the pre-tax savings and the tax shield, then subtract the tax.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$155,000+\$19,320-\$32,550\\[15 pt]
&=\$141,770
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for this project is $\$141,770$

Another value that we need to solve is the after tax salvage value. This is the amount paid for, after taxes, the asset when it will be sold. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax salvage value}&=\$55,000 \times(1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$43,450
\end{aligned}$$

The after-tax salvage value of the asset is $\$43,450$

Before we can solve for the net present value, we must first understand the concept of present value interest factor for annuity. This basically refers to the cash value of future payments. Using a table, we can see the annuity for the 5-year lifespan at $10\%$ discount rate. The annuity factor that we will use is $3.7908$. 

We will then multiply the operating cashflow by this factor to get the present value annuity

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present cash flow value}&=\$141,770 \times 3.7908\\[15 pt]
&=\$537,421.72
\end{aligned}$$

The present cash flow value that we will use for the computation of the net present value is $\$537,421.72$

To solve for the net present value, we will simply add all the present value of the cash inflows and subtract them from the initial investment and net working capital. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=[\$537,421.72+(\$43,450+\$29,000) \times 0.6209]\\
&-(\$460,000+\$29,000)\\[15 pt]
&=\$507,405.93
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of the project is $\$507,405.93$
